explanation_txt:

Since the reaction is exothermic, decrease in temperature causes reaction to proceed forward.

So, High pressure and Low temperature.

quest_title: If \(\cos 7\theta =\cos \theta -\sin 4\theta \), then the general value of \(\theta \) is:
explanation_txt:
\(\sin 4\theta =\cos \theta -\cos 7\theta \)

\(\Rightarrow\) \(\sin 4\theta =2\sin (4\theta )\sin (3\theta )\)

\( \Rightarrow \sin 4\theta (1 - 2 \sin 3 \theta) = 0 \)

\(\Rightarrow \) \(\sin 4\theta =0\) \(\Rightarrow \) \(4\theta =n\pi \)

or

\(\sin 3\theta =\cfrac{1}{2} =\sin \left(\cfrac{\pi }{6} \right)\)

\[\Rightarrow 3\theta =n\pi +(-1)^{n} \cfrac{\pi }{6} \]

\[\Rightarrow \theta =\cfrac{n\pi }{4} ,\, \cfrac{n\pi }{3} +(-1)^{n} \cfrac{\pi }{18} .\]
question_plain_title: If , then the general value of is:
explanation_plain_text: or

explanation_txt: \( \left| \begin{array} { r r r } { 6 i } & { - 3 i } & { 1 } \\ { 4 } & { 3 i } & { - 1 } \\ { 20 } & { 3 } & { i } \end{array} \right| = x + i y \\ \Rightarrow \left| \begin{array} { c c c } { 6 i + 4 } & { 0 } & { 0 } \\ { 4 } & { 3 i } & { - 1 } \\ { 20 } & { 3 } & { i } \end{array} \right| = x + i y \left[ R _ { 1 } \rightarrow R _ { 1 } + R _ { 2 } \right] \\ \begin{array} { l } { \Rightarrow ( 6 i + 4 ) \left( 3 i ^ { 2 } + 3 \right) = x + i y } \\ { \Rightarrow ( 6 i + 4 ) ( - 3 + 3 ) = x + i y } \\ { \Rightarrow \quad x + i y = 0 = 0 + i .0 \Rightarrow ( x , y ) = ( 0,0 ) } \end{array} \)

quest_title: The number of solutions of \(\cfrac{\log 5+\log (x^{2} +1)}{\log (x-2)} =2\) is
explanation_txt:
We have \(\cfrac{\log 5+\log (x^{2} +1)}{\log (x-2)} =2\)

\[\Rightarrow \log \{ 5(x^{2} +1)\} =\log (x-2)^{2} \Rightarrow 5(x^{2} +1)=(x-2)^{2} \]

\[\Rightarrow 4x^{2} +4x+1=0\Rightarrow x=-\cfrac{1}{2} \]

But for \(x=-\cfrac{1}{2}, \log (x-2)\) is not meaningful.

Hence it has no root.
question_plain_title: The number of solutions of is
explanation_plain_text:
We have

But for is not meaningful.

Hence it has no root.

quest_title: For the equation \(\cos ^{-1} x+\cos ^{-1} 2x+\pi =0\), the number of real solution is
explanation_txt:
\(\cos ^{-1} x+\cos ^{-1} (2x)=-\pi \)

\(\Rightarrow\) \(\cos ^{-1} 2x=-\pi -\cos ^{-1} x\)

\(\Rightarrow 2x=\cos (\pi +\cos ^{-1} x)\)

\(\Rightarrow 2x=\cos \pi (\cos \cos ^{-1} x)-\sin \pi \sin (\cos ^{-1} x)\)

\(\Rightarrow 2x=-x \)

\( \Rightarrow x=0\)

But \(x=0\) does not satisfy the given equation.

So, no solution will exist.

explanation_plain_text:

So, no solution will exist.

quest_title: If a has magnitude 5 and points north-east and vector b has magnitude 5 and points north-west, then \(|\, \, a-b\, \, |\, =\)
explanation_txt:
Since \(a\, \bot \, b\Rightarrow a\, .\, b=0\)

\[|a-b|^{2} =(a-b)^{2} =a^{2} +b^{2} -2a\, .\, b=25+25\]

\[\Rightarrow \, \, |a-b|\, \, =5\sqrt{2} .\]

quest_title: If \(i,\, \, j,\, \, k\) are unit orthonormal vectors, \(r\) is position vector, \(a\) is any vector and \(a\times r=j,\) then \( a . r \) is:
explanation_txt:
Since \(|a\times r|^{2} +|a\, .\, r|^{2} =|a|^{2} |r|^{2} \) \[\Rightarrow \, |j|^{2} +(a\, .\, r)^{2} =\, |a|^{2} |r|^{2} \Rightarrow \, (a\, .\, r)=\pm \sqrt{|a|^{2} |r|^{2} -1} \]

This shows that \(a\, .\, r\) depends on \(|r|\) for given \(a.\) Hence \(a\, .\, r\) is arbitrary scalar.

quest_title: A physical quantity is given by \(\quad X = M ^ { a } L ^ { b } T ^ { c } .\) The percentage error in measurement of \(M , L\) and \(T\) are \(\alpha , \beta\) and \(\gamma\) respectively. Then maximum percentage error in the quantity \(X\) is
explanation_txt:
Percentage error is given by \(\sum _{\text{all variables}}{\text{(exponent * % error in the variable)}}\)

\(\therefore X = a \alpha + b \beta + c \gamma\)

quest_title: Three concurrent forces of the same magnitude are in equilibrium. What is the angle between the forces? Also name the triangle formed by the forces as sides
explanation_txt:
In N forces of equal magnitude works on a single point and their resultant is zero then angle between any two forces is given

\(\theta = \cfrac { 360 } { N } = \cfrac { 360 } { 3 } = 120 ^ { \circ }\)

If these three vectors are represented by three sides of triangle, then they form equilateral triangle (180°-120°=60°)
question_plain_title: Three concurrent forces of the same magnitude are in equilibrium. What is the angle between the forces? Also name the triangle formed by the forces as sides
explanation_plain_text:
In N forces of equal magnitude works on a single point and their resultant is zero then angle between any two forces is given

If these three vectors are represented by three sides of triangle, then they form equilateral triangle (180°-120°=60°)

quest_title: A constant force \(\text{F}\) is applied on a body. The power (\(\text{P}\)) generated is related to the time elapsed as
explanation_txt:
\(P=\cfrac{F \cdot s}{t}=\cfrac{F \cdot \cfrac{1}{2} a t^{2}}{t}=\cfrac{F a t}{2}\)
\(\therefore \quad P \propto t\)

quest_title: If specific heat of a substance is infinite, it means
ans3_txt: No change in temperature takes place whether heat is taken in or given out
explanation_txt:
\(Q = m . c . \Delta \theta \Rightarrow c = \cfrac { Q } { m \cdot \Delta \theta } ; \text { when } \Delta \theta = 0 \Rightarrow c = \infty\)

\(\therefore\) Infinite value of specific heat means there is no change in temperature for any amount of heat gained or lost.
question_plain_title: If specific heat of a substance is infinite, it means
explanation_plain_text: Infinite value of specific heat means there is no change in temperature for any amount of heat gained or lost.
ans3_plain_text: No change in temperature takes place whether heat is taken in or given out

quest_title: A circular table of radius 'r' in which a bulb of luminous intensity I is suspended at a height 'h' directly above the center. The illuminance at edge is 1/8\({}^{th}\) of illuminance at centre then height is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{Ee}=1 / 8 \mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{e}}\)

\(\cfrac{\mathrm{I} \cos \theta}{\mathrm{r}^{2}+\mathrm{h}^{2}}=\cfrac{1}{8} \times \cfrac{1}{\mathrm{h}^{2}}\)

or, \(\cfrac{\mathrm{h}}{\left(\mathrm{r}^{2}+\mathrm{h}^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}}=\cfrac{1}{8 \mathrm{h}^{2}}\)

or, \(8 \mathrm{h}^{3}=\left(\mathrm{r}^{2}+\mathrm{h}^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}\)

or, \(2 \mathrm{h}^{3}=\left(\mathrm{r}^{2}+\mathrm{h}^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}\)

or, \(2 \mathrm{h}=\left(\mathrm{r}^{2}+\mathrm{h}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}\)

or, \(4 \mathrm{h}^{2}=\mathrm{r}^{2}+\mathrm{h}^{2} \)

or, \(\mathrm{h}=\cfrac{\mathrm{r}}{\sqrt{3}}\)

quest_title: Two identical light sources S1 and S2 emit light of same wavelength \(\lambda\). These light rays will exhibit interference if
explanation_txt: To see clear pattern of interference, phase of the light rays should be constant so that when path difference between lights becomes \(\cfrac{\lambda}{2}\) complete destructive interference takes place and light intensity at the point becomes zero.
question_plain_title: Two identical light sources S1 and S2 emit light of same wavelength . These light rays will exhibit interference if
explanation_plain_text: To see clear pattern of interference, phase of the light rays should be constant so that when path difference between lights becomes complete destructive interference takes place and light intensity at the point becomes zero.

quest_title: A sound wave has frequency 500Hz and velocity 360m/s (c)What is distance between two particles having phase difference 60\({}^{0}\) ?
explanation_txt:
\( \delta= \cfrac{2 \pi f}{v} \times \Delta x \)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta x=\cfrac{\cfrac{\pi}{3} \times 360}{2 \pi \times 500}=0.12 \mathrm{m}=12 \mathrm{cm} \)

quest_title: In Millikan's oil drop experiment a charged drop of mass 1.8 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-14}\) kg is stationary between its plates. The distance between its plates is 0.9 cm and potential difference is 2 kV. The number of electrons in the drop is
explanation_txt:
\(m_{\text {ail }}=1.8 \times 10^{-14} \mathrm{kg}\)
\(d=0.9 \mathrm{cm}=0.9 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{m}\)
\(V=2 \mathrm{kV}=2 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{volt}\)
\(n=?\)
\(e/m=1.8\times10^{11}\,C/kg\)
\(m g=q E\)
\(m g=n e \cfrac{V}{d}\)
\(n=\cfrac{m g d}{e V}=\cfrac{g d}{(e / m) V}\)

quest_title:
Radiation of wavelength \(180 \mathrm{nm}\) ejects photo-electrons from a plate of potassium whose work function is 2 eV. What is the maximum energy of the emitted electrons?
\(\left(e=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}, m_{e}=9 \times 10^{-31} \mathrm{kg}\right)\)
explanation_txt:
\(h f=\phi_{0}+\mathrm{K.E.}\)
\(\cfrac{h c}{\lambda}-\phi_{0}=\mathrm{K.E.}\)
\(\mathrm{K.E.}=\cfrac{h c}{\lambda}-\phi_{0}\)
question_plain_title: Radiation of wavelength ejects photo-electrons from a plate of potassium whose work function is 2 eV. What is the maximum energy of the emitted electrons?

quest_title: The curve of binding energy per nucleon as a function of atomic mass number has a sharp peak for helium nucleus. This implies that helium
explanation_txt:
The elements high on the E versus mass number plot are very tightly bound and hence, are stable. And the elements those are lower on this plot, are less tightly bound and hence, are unstable.

Since helium nucleus shows a peak on this plot so, it is very stable.
question_plain_title: The curve of binding energy per nucleon as a function of atomic mass number has a sharp peak for helium nucleus. This implies that helium
explanation_plain_text:
The elements high on the E versus mass number plot are very tightly bound and hence, are stable. And the elements those are lower on this plot, are less tightly bound and hence, are unstable.

Since helium nucleus shows a peak on this plot so, it is very stable.

quest_title: Beats are produced by two waves \(y_1=a\sin 200 \pi t\) and \(y_2=a\sin 208 \pi t \). The number of beats heard per second is:
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{y}_{1}=\mathrm{a} \sin 200 \pi \mathrm{t}\) and \(\mathrm{y}_{2}=\mathrm{a} \sin 208 \pi \mathrm{t}\)

\(\mathrm{f}_{1}=\cfrac{200 \pi}{2 \pi}=100 ;\,\, \mathrm{f}_{2}=\cfrac{208 \pi}{2 \pi}=104\)

No. of beats \(=\mathrm{f}_{2-} \mathrm{f}_{1}=4\)

quest_title: The figure below shows currents in a part of electric circuit. The current I is
explanation_txt:
According to Kirchhoff's first law,

At junction A, \(i _ { A B } = 2 + 2 = 4 A\)

At junction B, \(i _ { A B } = i _ { B C } - 1 = 3 A\)

At junction C, \(i = i _ { B C } - 1.3 = 3 - 1.3 = 1.7 \mathrm { amp }\)

quest_title: A circular ring of diameter 20 cm has a resistance of 0.01 \(\Omega\). The ring is turned from a position perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field of 2\(\text{T}\) to a position parallel to the field. The amount of charge flowing through the ring in this process is
explanation_txt:
\(E=-\cfrac{d \phi}{d t}=i R=\cfrac{d q}{d t} \times R\)
\(\begin{aligned} \therefore \quad & \text { Charge } q=\cfrac{\phi_{1}-\phi_{2}}{R} \\ & \text { Charge } q=\cfrac{2 \times \pi \times 0.1^{2}-0}{0.01} \\ &\text { Charge } q = 2\pi \text { Coulombs. } \end{aligned}\)
question_plain_title: A circular ring of diameter 20 cm has a resistance of 0.01 . The ring is turned from a position perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field of 2 to a position parallel to the field. The amount of charge flowing through the ring in this process is

quest_title: The magnetic susceptibility of a material of a rod is 499. Permeability of vacuum is 4\(\text{\(\pi\)}\)\(\times\) 10\({}^{-7}\) H/m. Absolute permeability of the material of the rod in henry/meter is
explanation_txt:
The magnetic susceptibility is given by
\(\begin{array}{l}{\chi_{m}=\cfrac{\mu}{\mu_{0}}-1} \\ {\Rightarrow \mu_{0}\left(1+\chi_{m}\right)=4 \pi \times 10^{-7}(1+499)} \\ {=2 \pi \times 10^{-4}}\end{array}\)
question_plain_title: The magnetic susceptibility of a material of a rod is 499. Permeability of vacuum is 4 10 H/m. Absolute permeability of the material of the rod in henry/meter is
explanation_plain_text: The magnetic susceptibility is given by
ans1_plain_text: 10
ans2_plain_text: 2 10
ans3_plain_text: 3 10
ans4_plain_text: 4 10

quest_title: A diatomic molecule has a dipole moment of 1.2 debye. If bond distance is \(\text{1.0A\(^{0}\),}\) the fraction of the electronic charge that exists on each atom is
explanation_txt:
Electronic charge \('e'=\cfrac{\text { Dipole moment }}{\text { Bond length }}\)
\[
\begin{array}{l}
{=\cfrac{1.2 \times 10^{-18} \mathrm{esucm}}{1.0 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{cm}}} \\
{=1.2 \times 10^{-10} \mathrm{esu}}
\end{array}
\]
Thus, fraction of electronic charge on each end
\(=\cfrac{1.2 \times 10^{-10}}{4.8 \times 10^{-10}}=0.25\)
\(
=25 \% \text { of }^{\prime} e^{\prime}
\)

quest_title: An electron in n = 1 orbit of hydrogen atom is bound by 13.6 eV. If a hydrogen atom is in the n = 3 state, how much energy is required to ionize it
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} \mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{i}} &=\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{\infty}}-\mathrm{E}_{3} \\ &=0-\cfrac{-13.6}{3^{2}}=1.51 \mathrm{eV} \end{aligned}\)
question_plain_title: An electron in n = 1 orbit of hydrogen atom is bound by 13.6 eV. If a hydrogen atom is in the n = 3 state, how much energy is required to ionize it
